qas.question: What was the biggest problem General Washington faced?
Where were the two major surrenders of British forces in the war?
What percentage of the Colonial population were loyal to the Crown?
What did Washington do after defeating the British Army?

answers.text: he retired quietly to his farm in Virginia.

qas.question: What advantage did Washington have over the British generals?

answers.text: he had a better idea of how to win the war than they did

qas.question: What was the smallest problem General Washington faced?
Where were the three major surrenders of British forces in the war?
What percentage of the Colonial population weren't loyal to the Crown?

plausible_answers.text: retired quietly to his farm in Virginia

qas.question: What did Washington not do after defeating the British Army?

plausible_answers.text: he had a better idea of how to win the war

qas.question: What disadvantage did Washington have over the British generals?

context: General George Washington (1732–99) proved an excellent organizer and administrator, who worked successfully with Congress and the state governors, selecting and mentoring his senior officers, supporting and training his troops, and maintaining an idealistic Republican Army. His biggest challenge was <a0_0><b5_0>logistics<b5_0/><a0_0/>, since neither Congress nor the states had the funding to provide adequately for the equipment, munitions, clothing, paychecks, or even the food supply of the soldiers. As a battlefield tactician Washington was often outmaneuvered by his British counterparts. As a strategist, however, <a4_0><b9_0>he had a better idea of how to win the war<b9_0/> than they did<a4_0/>. The British sent four invasion armies. Washington's strategy forced the first army out of Boston in 1776, and was responsible for the surrender of the second and third armies at <a1_0><b6_0>Saratoga (1777) and Yorktown (1781)<b6_0/><a1_0/>. He limited the British control to New York and a few places while keeping Patriot control of the great majority of the population. The Loyalists, on whom the British had relied too heavily, comprised about <a2_0><b7_0>20%<b7_0/><a2_0/> of the population but never were well organized. As the war ended, Washington watched proudly as the final British army quietly sailed out of New York City in November 1783, taking the Loyalist leadership with them. Washington astonished the world when, instead of seizing power, <a3_0>he <b8_0>retired quietly to his farm in Virginia<b8_0/>.
